sentences.sentence: The servant then got on Falada, and the Princess( 公主 ) got on the old horse, and they traveled on till they reached the royal castle( 城堡 ).
There was great joy( 喜悦 ) at their coming, and the King’s son hurried out to meet them.
He lifted the servant from her horse, thinking she was his bride( 新娘 ).
Then he led her up the stairs( 楼梯 ), while the real Princess had to remain below.
But the old King, who was looking out of the window, saw the real Princess standing in the yard.

The King noticed how delicate( 优雅的 ) and gentle and beautiful she was, and so he went down and asked the false( 假的 ) bride who it was that she had brought with her, who was now standing in the courtyard( 庭院 ).
“Oh!” answered the bride. “I only brought her with me for company.
Give her something to do, to keep her busy.”
But the old King could not think of any work to give her.
Finally, he remembered the boy he had who took care of the geese( 鹅 ), and thought that she might help him.
And so the real Princess was sent to look after the geese with the goose-boy, who was called Conrad.
Soon after that, the false bride said to the Prince( 王子 ),
“Dearest husband, I have a favor to ask of you.”
“Whatever it is, it shall be done,” he answered.
“Then” said she, “send for( 请（某人）来 ) the knacker( 废马屠夫 ), to take away the horse I came here upon, and cut off its head.
That horse caused me a lot of trouble on the journey.”
For she was afraid that the horse might tell her husband how she had behaved( 表现 ) to the Princess.
And when the order had been given that Falada should die, the Princess heard about it.
She came to the knacker secretly, and promised him a piece of gold if he would do something for her.
In the town there was a high, dark, and gloomy( 幽暗的 ) gateway( 出入口 ) through which she had to pass morning and evening with her geese.
She asked him to take Falada’s head and to fasten( 把...固定在 ) it above the gate, so that she might always see it as she passed by.
And the man promised, and he took Falada’s head and fastened it above the gateway.
Early next morning as she and Conrad drove their geese through the gate, she said as she went by,
Does Falada hang above the gate?
And the head answered,
Princess, we both regret your fate( 命运 ).
If your mother only knew,
Her heart would surely break in two.
But she went on through the town, driving her geese to the field.
And when they came into the meadows( 草地 ), she sat down and undid( 解开 ) her hair, which looked exactly like gold.
When Conrad saw how it shone, he wanted to pull out a few hairs for himself.
And she said,
Wind, blow Conrad’s hat away—
Don’t stop the windy weather
Until I fix my hair
And get myself together.
Then there came a wind strong enough to blow Conrad’s hat far away over the fields, and he had to run after it.
By the time he came back, she had put up her hair with combs( 梳子 ) and pins( 饰针 ), and he could not get at any to pull out.
He was so angry and would not speak to her.
So they looked after the geese until the evening came, and then they went home.
The next morning, as they passed under the dark gateway, the Princess said,
Does Falada hang above the gate?
And the head answered,
Princess, we both regret your fate.
If your mother only knew,
Her heart would surely break in two.
And when they reached the fields she sat down and began to comb( 梳理 ) out her hair.
Then Conrad came up and wanted to take some of it, and she cried,
Wind, blow Conrad’s hat away—
Don’t stop the windy weather
Until I fix my hair
And get myself together.
Then the wind came and blew Conrad’s hat very far away, so that he had to run after it.
When he came back again her hair was put up again, so that he could not pull any of it out.
Then they looked after the geese until the evening.
And after they had got home, Conrad went to the old King and said, “I will no longer look after the geese with that girl!”
“Why not?” asked the old King.
“Because she causes me trouble the whole day long,” answered Conrad.
Then the old King ordered him to explain.
“Every morning,” said Conrad, “as we pass under the dark gateway with the geese, there is an old horse’s head hanging on the wall, and she says to it,
Does Falada hang above the gate?
And the head answers,
Princess, we both regret your fate.
If your mother only knew,
Her heart would surely break in two."
And besides this, Conrad told the King everything that happened in the fields, and how he had to run after his hat.

article_info.previous: 公主因为婚约要远嫁别国，王后给公主准备了丰厚的嫁妆，公主会说话的马儿Falada也随行，王后还派了一名女仆照顾公主。但是女仆傲慢无礼，竟强迫公主与她互换身份。
article_info.share_words: The King noticed how delicate and gentle and beautiful she was, and so he went down and asked the false bride who it was that she had brought with her, who was now standing in the courtyard.

question.en: What did the King send the Princess to do?

analysis: 文中提到：“But the old King could not think of any work to give her. Finally, he remembered the boy he had who took care of the geese, and thought that she might help him. And so the real Princess was sent to look after the geese with the goose-boy, who was called Conrad.”因此答案选C。

question.cn: 为什么女仆要求王子杀掉Falada？
question.en: Why did the servant girl ask the Prince to kill Falada?

options.cn: 因为Falada在旅途中带给她很多麻烦。
options.en: Because Falada caused her lots of trouble on the journey.
Because she was afraid Falada might tell the truth.

analysis: 文中提到：“For she was afraid that the horse might tell her husband how she had behaved to the Princess.”因此答案选B。

question.cn: 大风是怎么帮助公主的？
question.en: How did the Wind help the Princess?

analysis: 文中提到：“Then there came a wind strong enough to blow Conrad’s hat far away over the fields, and he had to run after it.” 因此答案选C。
